segments.text: for promotion and tenure were good standards in the department kind of tough there were a couple of people that came through who didn't make who were actually let go uh so as uh dean as dean byers becomes vice president for academic affairs earl cook follows him correct describe earl cook as the dean
Well, Earl was a little different than Byers.
I don't really remember too much.
He was more involved than Byers was.
But you could never go by that, because Byers was such a quiet kind of guy.
And things got done, and things were really running very well under Byers' tenure.
Cook continued that.
He continued to do a good job.
He was more visible and more vocal.
But the quality of the college stayed high during his tenure.
For a guy over in the history department then, I and my colleagues thought geosciences got favorite treatment.
We thought you all were living off the good land.
We were.
There's no question about that.
I think that's true.
I think we did get favored treatment.
We didn't teach very many courses.
We had a lot of research.
Some of our faculty were very highly paid.
I was not one of them.
But I can understand why you felt that way in history.

When you got here, the decision had already been made for women to be admitted, the Corps to be volunteer, racial integration, higher admission requirements, but we didn't yet have women's dormitories.
Were there some female students in geophysics in your early years?
Oh, there weren't.
The first few years, there weren't any.
As a matter of fact, there were a lot of core kids that were in the geophysics program.
But shortly thereafter, after the first few years, we then got a big influx of female, women students.
And they were amongst our best students, no question about it.
I've always felt this was a bad way
waste of a resource not to take the women and make them part of our society.
Even today, we have these glass ceilings or whatever they are.
Bad sets of criteria that they keep people who can do things from doing the things that they should do, make the contributions that they can make.
Earl Rudder was president when you first got here.
Do you remember any impressions you and your colleagues had of him?
Yeah, he was a tough guy.
But at the same time, he was a hard-working guy.
He was really interested in A&M.
He really wanted to make it into a first-class university.
I think that was clear.
I do remember one thing, though.
I talked to him after one meeting, and I asked him, why don't you set up the faculty senate?
I said, it would be to your advantage to have one.
And he just gave me this one look which indicated, look it, buddy.
The troops don't tell the generals what's going to happen around here.
So he was sort of an authoritarian figure.
Of course, all of A&M at that point was very authoritarian.
It was not very democratic.
I think we've gone a little too democratic.
at this point to tell you the truth.
I sort of have the feeling that we have the inmates running the asylum and we could use a little more of that tough leadership at the head.
Do you remember President Rudder coming to speak to the geosciences faculty?
No, I don't.
He may have, but I don't remember.
I don't remember many such college-level functions.
Then when he died in 1970, Jack Williams became the president.
Do you have any recollections of him?
It seemed like he did a pretty competent job.
I did not interact very much with the president.
I was busy here in the troops, on the front lines, dealing with students and the other faculty.
And I've never gotten very interested in administration.
I've never tried to get into administration.
And of course, I never have, other than being acting head for a couple of years.
Under Williams, they built some women's dorms.
That was one of his conditions.
Accepting the job was that he could designate a dorm
in January of 71 that would be for women, take an existing dorm.
You don't remember any sudden change in women in geophysics, do you?
Well, that's about when it happened, yes.
It was in the early 70s.
I could go, I got my grade book there, I could look and we could see what the males and the females are if you're really interested.
Oh, now that reminds me of something.
What was your
What was your grading methodology?
Did you grade on the curve, or on what basis did you assign grades?
Yeah, I graded on a curve, essentially.
But it was not an absolute curve.
As a matter of fact, most of the exams that I gave were generally three or four questions with two or three parts to them.
They were generally problem solving and writing type questions.
They were not multiple choice.
And so I couldn't do it on the grade by
by the numbers sort of thing.
Of course, but again, there were 15 kids in the class.
And it really would have been unconscionable on my part to make a multiple choice test in the grade that way.
So each exam was gone over with a fine tooth comb.
Multiple partial credit was given to all the students.
And I found, as a matter of fact, I even wrote a paper
that with 10 students, you could easily get a Gaussian distribution.
And it may be a distribution with one of the tails missing or something like that.
Usually, the lower tail was generally missing.
But you can tell.
You know that there are really bright kids in the class, and they get to the top grade.
And you look at how it starts to tail on off.
If it tails off tremendously down to the last guy, well, then maybe he should flunk.
But if it tails off not all that much on down to the last guy, well, obviously this kid has learned something.
And I also had some absolute standards as to what I wanted the kids to learn from my course.
So I looked to see if they had gotten that much information out of it.
So I failed very few kids.
But that's not surprising because, first of all, they were all seniors, mostly all seniors or juniors, the undergraduates, number one.
And they were, in this group of kids, a really super bright number two.
So I felt that if anybody really failed, it was my fault more than theirs.
Looking back over 30 years, did you come to any general impression about which high schools produced some of the best students?
No, not really.
I don't think I ever really paid attention to that.
So they were scattered in terms of background.
Yeah, because we didn't have that many students.
And it's not like we were getting a lot of students from Texas that we could look at it.
And so therefore, we really paid attention to the SAT scores and the grade point averages and the letters of recommendation and not so much which school it was.
But I do recall there were some schools that we felt more favorably inclined to.
And I don't remember which ones they were, but there were some schools that had a better reputation.
In those early years, you taught, you said, two or sometimes three courses.
Right.
What were those courses, and what was the general content of your normal workload?
OK.
The courses were exploration, seismology,
which had a lab associated with it.
And so it was three hours of lectures, three hours of- Junior?
That was a senior level course.
There was a junior level course which was experimental exploration geophysics, which also had a lab associated with it.
It was three hours lecture and a four hour lab.
And let's see, there was also, the other course was the physics of the Earth's interior.
And I've also taught the geophysical data processing, which is how to manipulate the seismic data and digital data and handle stuff like that.
Those are the undergraduate courses.
But I also taught the graduate level courses in theoretical seismology, continuum mechanics, physics of the Earth's interior, a migration course.
What were some of the others?
I did a...
Theoretical seismology, earthquake seismology.
Yeah, the theoretical seismology.
I never did do the gravity and magnetics at the graduate level.
Dave Falk was always did that one.
But those were the ones that I taught.
And then, of course, the seminar courses.
Who was the departmental student advisor in the late 60s and 70s?
I was the graduate advisor all that time.
We only had one, of course.
The undergraduate advisor, I believe, rotated.
Rick Carlson did it for a while, but even before then, Dave Falkus was the one who seemed to spend most of the time at it.
He was always very, very interested in the students.
Of course, Terry Spencer also would advise the students, but only when there were problems the department had.
Again, there weren't very many students, so there really wasn't a lot of work to do.
As the graduate advisor, what were normally the topics that you needed to help them with?
What were their problems?
Yeah, the problem was they weren't as good as our own undergraduates.
And what they really need was the math and the physics.
Most of them had the geology, and they didn't have the math and the physics.
And that was the one that we needed to get them into.
We had a lot of them who spent the first year or so doing our undergraduate courses.
actually, because they didn't have them as undergraduates.
And they got credit at a time where you did a master's degree, you could get credit for undergraduate courses, and it was worthwhile.
And the graduate students would object to being in those undergraduate courses because the undergraduates were so good, made it tough for them.
You know, usually the undergrads complain that you've got graduate students in the courses, they're making it harder.
Well, this was the other way around, actually.
So our graduate students weren't as good as their undergraduates.
But those were the courses.
Now, surely you must remember some stories of some student offering some excuse that didn't make sense for a problem.
There probably was a bunch of those stories, but those are the kind of things that I just kind of slough them off, you know, and I really don't think about them.
I don't like to dwell on those things.
I like to dwell more on the positive things rather than the, and I've never been a collector of stories.
Bob Berger's one, and I know you are one.
You're just tremendous at it, and I'm just not, I'm just not very interested, so I don't remember them well, unfortunately.
Right.
You describe your,
beginning and your progress as a researcher here.
What did you start working on and trace that along?
Well, I started as a researcher when I was a graduate student at UCLA and did work in
wave propagation primarily.
Then when I went to Space General, I worked on antennas and communication systems.
As a matter of fact, I did an analysis of what today is a GPS system because the satellites were just coming into use at that time.
People were already thinking about using satellites for detecting locations on the ground.
As a matter of fact, they had it the other way around.
They had a system whereby

uh a downed pilot would have a transmitter that transmitter would transmit up to the satellite the satellite would as it went on by would pick up the signal and then retransmit it to the thing there and on the basis of the time that it was received and so forth so they could pinpoint the guy so he asked me to do a calculation on that to see just how accurately they could pinpoint it and i remember i did a calculation that came out to be something like a tenth of a meter
or something like that.
I was really just fascinated.
Of course, I failed to take into account some of the real serious problems, like effects of the atmosphere and noise and jitter in the oscillators and so forth.
And then from there, when I went to MIT, I did electromagnetic wave propagation, underground communication.
So I was in electrical parts.
But then when I went to MIT, I could have continued with the electrical part.
But Ted Madden was already there, and he was doing the electrical stuff.
There was nobody doing the seismic.
I had done the seismic before, so I did the seismic.
So I did the seismic stuff.
And of course, I had been doing a lot of data processing and communication theory stuff, and so I got into the data processing stuff as well.
The laser strain meter was kind of an outshoot of my electronics and servo mechanism background and so forth.
And then when I got here, I sort of did the same thing.
I got more into data processing, into theoretical geophysics.
I looked at the chemistry and physics of the Earth, phase changes and so forth, stuff like that.
I've got maybe 60 publications.
All of which are different.
There has not been any one field that I've really spent my time in other than geophysics.
Looking at that 60 some odd publications, which was the first one that really you were proud to claim?
Actually, it was the second paper I did.
It was with Leon Knopoff, an undergraduate student.
It was on seismic reciprocity.
And it's still referenced today.
And as a matter of fact, I still write papers, and still people talk to me about that.
And some people call me Mr.
Reciprocity.
But that was just one of the subjects.
So that one had the biggest impact.
There were a couple others that were pretty important.
I did the self-focusing antenna arrays, servo mechanism.
I did the communication system, the underground communications.
And there's a bunch of other ones, too.
I'm glad to tell you about them.
All right, after you got here, which was the first one that you were proud to mention to your colleagues and so forth?
Well, there's been a couple of them.
The first one was looking at the moho as a solid-solid phase change.
And making the assumption that the moho is a solid-solid phase change, the moho is down around 30 kilometers or so below the surface of the Earth, is that there's a density change.
And from that, one can get
One could build mountains or make oceans.
And so we did an analysis to show how this could go about.
Unfortunately, nobody accepts that theory, believes that the Moho is a phase change.
They think it's a chemical change.
But that was one of the first ones that I thought that was really important.
Another one I did was the non-linear least squares thing, which was
really important in terms of the inverse theory of being able to extract parameters from data from nonlinear problems.
Most people have solved linear problems in the past.
I did the nonlinear one and looked at the case of creep and salt as a
and did some work, and the creep and salt was applied.
This nonlinear inverse theory was applied to creep and salt.
So that's another one that is very important.
Then one more recently, well, it's not so recent, 78 or so, is the bed of nails model.
It's the model for the variation of velocity and permeability as a function of pressure.
And nobody had done a good theoretical model before I did it, and I did it.
People still don't use it as much as they should, but they will, I'm sure.
So at first you worked in the atmosphere, but then you began to work underground.
Right.
Some of it applied.
Well, it all was underground, actually, because the seismic wave propagation was also underground.
But that was seismic.
Then it went to the atmosphere.
The ionosphere got involved in the electromagnetic propagation.
But actually, that was propagation with the antennas in the ground.
It was supposed to be communication between command posts and missile sites.
But nevertheless, the communication actually went up to the ionosphere through the atmosphere.
In those early years, did the department have any game plan?
Were there some goals for the department?
What did you all hope it would be?
Well, we hoped that what we would do is develop some good students and develop a reputation so that we would have a national reputation.
We developed a little bit of one.
I think we certainly developed a good one in exploration geophysics.
We never did develop a very good reputation in classical geophysics.
We'd also built up a very good reputation in tectonophysics with the guys in the Center for Tectonophysics.
But the plan, of course, was to have a good program, a quality program that would bring fame and fortune to all of us.
What other institutions were kind of the model, hoping to be in the same league with whom?
Well, of course, we would like to have been in the league of MIT, Caltech, UCLA, Columbia, Lamont-Doherty.
Were there any regional schools that you all wanted to at least stay better than?
Who were the regional competitors?
Let's see.
Actually, there weren't any.
The University of Texas at that point had a very weak program in geophysics.
Rice had a program.
They had a pretty good, and some aspects of it were good.
But it wasn't as strong a program as ours.
If anything, the program that did develop for a while, and now has sort of gone down the drain, is one at the University of Houston.
And then it sort of died back there.
So yeah, we were always in competition with those regional programs.
And of course, the University of Texas program has gotten much better in the recent past.
Were there any opportunities that were missed in the early years for the department that you can think of?
Yeah, I think there were a lot of missed opportunities.
The department really would have been a lot better off if we had all worked together more.
You mean as a team?
As a team, yeah.
Whereas it seemed like everybody was pulling their own way, their own direction.
Of course, I was no help either.
It's not like saying it's everybody else's fault but mine.
But I think that if we had gotten together and cooperated more, it would have made it into a much better department.
Spencer was the department head at first.
How long did he serve?
He served for about ten years.
Who followed him?
I was the acting head for two years.
Describe what it was like to be the acting department head.
It was great, really.
Everybody said that it was going to be tough to be acting head and that I couldn't get along with people and so forth and so on.
Actually, it turned out I had less problems when I was acting head than when I was not acting head.
Because I guess I was always fighting the system.
When I was acting head, I was the system.
And I had my own ideas about how things should be done.
And I usually had my way of doing things.
And the way in which it was, I would say, this is the way we're going to do it.
If you have any objections, tell me what your objections are and why.
And if you don't have any objections, this is the way we're going to do it.
So it worked out all right for a while there.
We made some good progress.
We hired some good people and got some good students and so forth.
And then we got Neville Carter to come.
He was the guy who...
Describe him and his strengths.
His strengths were his people strengths.
He was a good guy for getting people involved and getting people to work together.
And he set up the business of doing the five-year plan.

kind of thing where we would have retreats and you say what are we going to do in the next five years and stuff like that and actually that was a very good idea and it it helped I'm sure because we did things we looked about which way the department wanted to go and who we were going to try to hire and how we were going to go get students and so forth and so on so so he's he was a
Also, he was a very good researcher.
He did some excellent research in salt, which was his main area of interest.
He was department head, do you say, five years?
Yeah, I think he was about five years.
And then who follows him?
I believe Errol Hoskins did.
Describe him.
Well, Earl was a very low-key guy.
And so things were just kind of quiet, and they just sort of just went along.
And actually, I think that was about the time when the oil business was getting in trouble anyway.
And so there really wasn't much you could do except sort of pull your ears in and just hope that you could end up surviving.
And we survived.
How did the downturn in oil prices and so forth in the 80s, how did that affect the department?
It affected the department quite a bit in the number of students that would come on in.
The enrollment went down quite a bit.
The quality of the students went down.
quite a bit, both as a graduate and the undergraduate program.
So it made a big difference.
It didn't go down as badly as it might because we did have other strengths.
We weren't just an oil company school, but that was one of our main areas.
And so we were hurt by the oil industry.
Did the contributions from the corporations go down also?
Yes.
So scholarships were harder to produce?
Right.
And the number of employment opportunities for the graduates went down.
Yes, but it wasn't really too bad, because the way it was before is every one of our graduates would end up with five or six offers when they graduated.
And so now they only had one or two.
It would break my heart, because these were all good, high-quality companies.
And I've always felt that the kids were better off if they didn't go to work for an oil company.
If they did something different than that, they probably would have an even better, more interesting, and more profitable career.
Because my father always told me, he says, Tony, the best way to be a poor man is to take a job that you like and to work at it.
And that's, of course, what I've done.
And I've ended up being a poor man because of that.
In these 30 years, what have been the changes in where a geophysics graduate gets a job?
I don't think there really have been any changes.
There always was.
The government was a strong place.
Academia was a strong place.
There are all the government labs, for example, and of course the oil industry, the resource industry.
It's slowed down a little bit in terms of the resource industry, but it's still there.
And all the other places are still there.
But the other thing is we give them a good training.
Kids get trained in the Earth.
They know about the Earth.
They know math.
They know physics.
They know logical thinking, problem solving.
And we force them to take courses in English, history, political science, and all that.
We've always felt that the student should be more than just a scientist.
And so they come out with a tremendous education.
I mean, hell, they could be a history major.
What would they do then?
So I've always felt that the kids had a good education if they're going into geophysics.
I never felt worried about getting a job, that they could always get a job.
And I used to tell them that a good guy

person knows how to do something never has to worry about getting a job because there are so few people in the world that know how to do anything now the and the kind of job the salaries that they started out with yes would if we had constant buying power dollars would those salaries have kind of followed the price of oil per barrel um like salaries this year are better than they were
in constant dollars four or five years ago?
No, not really.
I mean, there's so much profit and so much slop in the oil business that the price of the oil is really almost immaterial, I think.
Of course, you get on down to it.
There's a finding cost.

developing costs and so forth for oil is somewhere maybe three four dollars a barrel and it's never and now you know in today's money and it's never been that that price in the last well there's certainly 20 years and before 30 years ago when it was down around three dollars a barrel why then the costs were about a dollar or something like that so so there's always been a lot of money in there so the
The salaries that the kids get, I think, are more dependent upon the competition about other people who would hire them.
It's not so much been the price of the oil, because whatever profits are available on these things here, that was taken by the executives.
They would give bonuses and go to the shareholders.
It never went to the workers.
I don't think there ever was any real fluctuation in terms of that.
There was a fluctuation in terms of the number of students that were hired, the number of positions that were available, but I don't think there was that much fluctuation in salaries.
Did you all begin to attract international students?
Yes.
When?
That's been the more recent past.
Well, we always had international students in our graduate program, as a matter of fact.
Primarily from what areas in the world?
We had them initially from India and then from Taiwan.
And I see that for a long time.
That was it.
And then Korea was another place where we had a strong number of excellent students that came on in, got their education here in the United States.
It was at the time when we didn't have a big reputation.
And so we had difficulty trying to attract high quality American students into the program.
This is the graduate program again.
And so we did have a lot of foreign students.
More recently, however, the department does have a reputation, so we have guys coming from Saudi Arabia, Malaysia, from Indonesia, from Russia, China, all over the place, wherever there's
We've had students from South America, Central America.
And you all did not do any specific recruiting in those overseas areas, did you?
No, no we did not.
They came on their own?
They came on their own, but as soon as they made an inquiry, well, we immediately started talking to them, and we didn't let any prospect get away, or at least we worked on them very assiduously.
And you did not mention many European or other Western hemisphere.
No, there weren't many.
There were some who came to the Center for Tectonal Physics, because we had a gal from Italy and a couple from Germany that came to tectonal physics.
But most of the ones that were in the petroleum business came from the Far East and South America.
Did you and your colleagues ever form any general ideas about which areas produced the most diligent students, the brightest students, which international areas?
Not in the USA.
Well, actually, you know, most foreign students always work a lot harder.
Okay.
I think of the ones who haven't worked hard, there's been only one place.
There's a kid from, let's see, from Thailand.
I guess it's Thailand.
It just couldn't seem, it may have been just that one individual.
He just couldn't seem to get anything done.
But most of the time, the graduate students have been very hard workers.
Ah, yes.
